Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Community ecology of partial consumption: Integrating plant demography into herbivore competition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecologists are well-equipped with theory for competition between species that consume and deplete shared resources. Resource depletion, i.e., consuming resources quickly enough to limit the resources available to other consumers, is a well-established pathway by which different consumer species interact. Unfortunately, approaches based on resource depletion apply to only a subset, and perhaps a minority, of consumer-resource interactions in nature. Many consumer species consume resource organisms only partially, and do not appear substantially to reduce available resources. This includes many herbivores, which leave much green plant material unconsumed; non-fatal parasites, parasitoids, and pathogens, whose hosts can continue to forage, mate, and otherwise go about life while infected; and mutualists such as pollinators, defenders, and cleaners, which collect rewards provided by hosts in return for these services. A key feature of such species interactions is that resource organisms respond to partial consumption via changes in their survival, growth, and reproduction. The effects of these demographic responses on resource competition have been little studied. Building on previous promising theoretical results showing that resource demographic responses can critically affect the outcome of competition, this project will develop mathematical theory to accomplish three goals. First, general theory will establish the different possible roles of the demography of partial consumption in biological settings, ranging from competition between herbivores to competition for access to mutualistic partners. Second, models will integrate plant demographic responses to herbivore attack with other known pathways of interaction between the different herbivores of a shared plant host. Third, applications such as biological control of resource populations will be investigated quantitatively.

The theory developed in this project will have broad application within and potentially beyond the ecological sciences. Further, the project will support the quantitative training and mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher in the construction and analysis of mathematical models to address ecological questions, as well as training in presenting results to non-mathematical audiences. Attempts will be made to recruit applicants from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. Postdoctoral involvement will also broaden dissemination of research results through increased publication and presentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary endeavor of mathematical theory is to make general predictions regarding the outcomes of hypothesized processes. This purpose is distinct from making specific predictions about particular populations or environments, yet must acknowledge empirical discoveries and data. Along multiple directions, this project brings together accumulated (or accumulating) findings about partial consumption—where at least species consumes some part of a resource, and the remaining resource responds to that consumption—and simple, general model approaches that highlight established principles of species interactions, such as mechanisms that can enable multiple competing species to coexist.

 

One major effort has been to understand mutually beneficial interactions as reciprocal partial consumption. For instance, many plants obtain soil nutrients not directly from the soil, but from mycorrhizal fungi, whereas fungi obtain carbon from plants. This aspect of the project has supported a female postdoctoral associate to study whether and how different fungi most benefit plants as plant needs change through time. Her work has shown how the optimal balance of fungi should change as soil nutrient status changes, and also has shown definitively that, in the absence of any other factors, it can be best for plants to support more than one type of fungi through time. This coexistence of different fungi is an important finding for diversity maintenance more generally, as previous studies have required other processes to maintain multiple fungi.

 

The project has supported other mutualism work. I have shown that the different demographic effects of partial consumption by a beneficial and a harmful species on a shared resource can lead to coexistence of both consumer species, and that the harmful species exerts a key restraint on the positive feedback between the beneficial species and its resource. This is a new and important finding both for diversity maintenance and for general perspectives on the population and community dynamics of beneficial interactions. Beneficial interactions are so common in nature that it is urgent to advance our general quantitative understanding of how they operate. Additional work on other aspects of beneficial interactions is still ongoing; I have summarized these two projects because they are complete and their findings have been published in leading ecological journals.

 

Finally, I have developed new approaches for quantifying how factors such as partial consumption, through simultaneous effects on many life transitions (such as survival, fecundity, or growth to different developmental stages) can affect overall population growth in variable environments. For instance, deer herbivory can affect all of plant survival, fecundity, and growth, each to different extents; the amount and effects of herbivory can fluctuate from year as deer population and deer and plant nutritional status change; and other factors that also affect plant survival, fecundity, and growth can additionally change from year to year. How can we know how the overall plant population will increase or decrease as a result of fluctuating herbivory, against a background of other variability? How can we answer similar questions about climate, as climate can similarly affect multiple plant transitions simultaneously? Previous work has focused on single life transitions, all else being held constant. I developed measures to answer how population growth would respond to changes in the average intensity of a variable, multifaceted driving factor, such as herbivory or rainfall, and to the year-to-year variability in that driving factor. One key novel feature is the use of data from an empirical design that is well-established for a different purpose. This study was also published prominently, and I am working to continue to demonstrate its usefulness to broad scientific audiences, particularly as it could help in the study of evolutionary responses to multifaceted factors.

 

The project's primary broader impacts are quantitative training and career development for a postdoctoral researcher, the PI, and a PhD student, all female. Some current work on beneficial interactions involves collaboration with bioengineers, and other current work on population responses to driving factors involves collaboration between a theorist (the PI) and an empirically oriented colleague.
